title: Genesis Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Genesis chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Genesis Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Genesis Chapter 21.

questions.question: Who was born to Abraham and Sarah in their old age according to Genesis 21?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaac
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:2-3 states that Sarah bore Abraham a son named Isaac in his old age.

questions.question: At what age was Isaac circumcised according to God's command?
questions.correctAnswer: 8 days old
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:4 explains that Abraham circumcised Isaac when he was eight days old as God had commanded.

questions.question: How old was Abraham when Isaac was born?
questions.correctAnswer: 100 years old
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:5 states that Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born.

questions.question: What did Sarah say God had made her do, causing laughter?
questions.correctAnswer: Laugh
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:6 records Sarah saying, 'God hath made me to laugh,' meaning joy and laughter.

questions.question: Who was mocking Isaac, leading Sarah to ask Abraham to cast them out?
options: The son of Hagar the Egyptian
questions.correctAnswer: The son of Hagar the Egyptian
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:9-10 tells that Sarah saw the son of Hagar mocking Isaac and requested Abraham to send them away.

questions.question: According to Genesis 21, who said that in Isaac shall Abraham's seed be called?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: In Genesis 21:12, God instructs Abraham to listen to Sarah and that in Isaac his seed shall be called.

questions.question: Where did Hagar wander after being sent away with her son?
questions.correctAnswer: Wilderness of Beersheba
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:14 states that Hagar and her son wandered in the wilderness of Beersheba after being sent away.

questions.question: What did Hagar do when the water was spent in the bottle while in the wilderness?
options: Cast the child under a shrub and wept
questions.correctAnswer: Cast the child under a shrub and wept
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:15-16 describes Hagar casting her son under a shrub and weeping when the water was gone.

questions.question: Who called out to Hagar from heaven and reassured her?
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of God
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:17 records that the angel of God called to Hagar from heaven and reassured her not to fear.

questions.question: What did God show Hagar to save her son?
questions.correctAnswer: A well of water
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:19 says God opened Hagar's eyes to see a well of water which she used to give her son drink.

questions.question: True or False: Abraham made a covenant with Abimelech because of a well of water.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:25-27 describes Abraham reproving Abimelech over a well and making a covenant with him.

questions.question: True or False: Abraham called the place where they made a covenant Beersheba because they swore there.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:31 states that the place was called Beersheba because both swore an oath there.

questions.question: True or False: Abraham took a wife for his son in the land of Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:21 notes that Abraham's son dwelt in Paran and his mother took him a wife out of Egypt.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Abraham planted a ______ in Beersheba and called on the name of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: grove
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:33 states that Abraham planted a grove in Beersheba and called on the name of the LORD.

questions.question: What did Abraham set by themselves as a witness for the well he dug?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven ewe lambs
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:28-30 mentions Abraham setting seven ewe lambs by themselves as a witness for the well.

medium.title: Genesis Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Genesis Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God's timing for life events. Based on Genesis 21, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God fulfills His promises at the appointed time.
We must force things to happen on our own schedule.
Doubt is a sign that God is not working.
God only acts when we are ready.
questions.correctAnswer: God fulfills His promises at the appointed time.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:1-2 shows that the LORD visited Sarah and she conceived at the set time God had spoken, demonstrating that God's timing is perfect and trustworthy. This encourages faith and patience in God's promises.

questions.question: How does Genesis 21 teach about obedience in family life?
options: Abraham circumcised Isaac on the eighth day as God commanded.
Abraham delayed circumcision until Isaac was older.
Sarah decided the religious practices for Isaac.
God did not require any physical signs for Isaac.
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham circumcised Isaac on the eighth day as God commanded.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:4 records Abraham obeying God's command to circumcise Isaac on the eighth day, showing the importance of following God's instructions in family and spiritual disciplines.

questions.question: What does Sarah's reaction to Isaac's birth teach us about gratitude and joy in God's blessings?
options: She said God made her laugh, and all who heard would laugh with her.
She was silent and kept the joy to herself.
She doubted the blessing at first.
She immediately planned a feast without expressing joy.
questions.correctAnswer: She said God made her laugh, and all who heard would laugh with her.
questions.explanation: In Genesis 21:6, Sarah expresses joy and gratitude by acknowledging God made her laugh, sharing her happiness openly. This encourages believers to celebrate God's blessings with thankful hearts.

questions.question: A believer is facing family conflict over inheritance. Based on Genesis 21, what principle about family unity and God's plan would you share?
options: God established Isaac as the heir, and his role should be respected.
All children must have equal inheritance regardless of God's promise.
Family disputes should be settled by human strength alone.
God does not concern Himself with family matters.
questions.correctAnswer: God established Isaac as the heir, and his role should be respected.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:10-12 shows Sarah's concern for Isaac's inheritance and God's confirmation that Isaac is the promised heir, teaching respect for God's chosen plan and guidance in family roles.

questions.question: How does Genesis 21 illustrate trusting God during trials and hardships?
options: Hagar trusted God when she and Ishmael were sent away and provided for.
Hagar gave up hope immediately after being sent away.
Abraham returned to rescue Hagar without faith.
God abandoned Hagar in the wilderness.
questions.correctAnswer: Hagar trusted God when she and Ishmael were sent away and provided for.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:14-19 records Hagar's distress but God's intervention by opening her eyes to a well of water and promising a great nation for Ishmael, illustrating trust and perseverance in God's care during trials.

questions.question: What does Abraham’s covenant with Abimelech teach about honesty and integrity in business and relationships?
options: Abraham reproved Abimelech for taking a well by force and made a covenant to settle it.
Abraham ignored the wrongdoing to avoid conflict.
Abimelech stole the well without any consequences.
Abraham acted dishonestly to gain the well.
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham reproved Abimelech for taking a well by force and made a covenant to settle it.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:25-32 shows Abraham confronting injustice with integrity and settling the matter through a covenant, teaching believers the importance of honesty and reconciliation in relationships.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about prayer not being answered. How does Genesis 21 encourage perseverance in prayer?
options: God heard the voice of Ishmael and sent an angel to encourage Hagar.
God ignores the cries of those in distress.
Prayer is only effective when everyone agrees.
God only answers prayers when they are easy.
questions.correctAnswer: God heard the voice of Ishmael and sent an angel to encourage Hagar.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:17-19 recounts God hearing Ishmael's cries and actively intervening, showing that God listens and responds to persistent prayer especially in desperate times.

questions.question: How does Genesis 21 demonstrate the importance of spiritual legacy in family life?
options: Isaac is named as the one through whom Abraham’s descendants will be called.
Ishmael was chosen to carry on Abraham’s spiritual legacy.
Abraham had no concern for his descendants’ spiritual future.
questions.correctAnswer: Isaac is named as the one through whom Abraham’s descendants will be called.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:12 emphasizes that through Isaac, Abraham's seed will be called, highlighting the importance of spiritual legacy and God’s plan in family and faith.

questions.question: True or False: Abraham planted a grove and called on the name of the LORD, the everlasting God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:33 shows Abraham planting a grove and calling on the LORD, demonstrating devotion and worship as a practical spiritual discipline.

questions.question: True or False: Sarah was pleased to keep Hagar and Ishmael in the household alongside Isaac without any conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:9-10 describes Sarah seeing Ishmael mocking and requesting Abraham to send away Hagar and Ishmael, showing that conflict arose and difficult decisions were made in obedience to God’s plan.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Abraham called the name of his son _____, whom Sarah bore to him.
questions.correctAnswer: Isaac
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:3 states Abraham named his son Isaac, fulfilling God’s promise and establishing his identity in the family line.

questions.question: How does Genesis 21 encourage believers to respond to trials involving family separation?
options: Trust God’s provision and care despite separation, as Hagar experienced.
Give up hope when family is separated.
Try to repair relationships only by human effort.
Ignore God’s guidance and act independently.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s provision and care despite separation, as Hagar experienced.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:14-21 shows Hagar and Ishmael sent away but cared for by God, teaching trust and reliance on God even in painful family separations.

questions.question: What lesson about generosity and stewardship can be learned from Abraham’s actions in Genesis 21?
options: Abraham gave bread and water to Hagar and Ishmael when sending them away.
Abraham refused to provide for Hagar and Ishmael.
Abraham ignored the needs of others.
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham gave bread and water to Hagar and Ishmael when sending them away.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:14 highlights Abraham’s provision of bread and water, showing responsible stewardship and generosity even in difficult circumstances.

questions.question: What does the covenant between Abraham and Abimelech teach about reconciliation and peace-making?
options: They resolved conflict through a covenant and mutual respect.
questions.correctAnswer: They resolved conflict through a covenant and mutual respect.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:27-32 recounts how Abraham and Abimelech settled their dispute with a covenant, demonstrating the biblical value of pursuing peace and reconciliation.

questions.question: How does Genesis 21 encourage humility and contentment in God's provision?
options: God provided a well of water to Hagar when she thought all was lost.
Hagar demanded more resources than God provided.
Abraham tried to solve problems without trusting God.
Sarah doubted God's ability to provide.
questions.correctAnswer: God provided a well of water to Hagar when she thought all was lost.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:19 teaches that God opened Hagar’s eyes to water in the wilderness, encouraging humility and contentment in trusting God’s timely provision during hardships.

hard.title: Genesis Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Genesis Chapter 21.

questions.question: What is the significance of Isaac's name as given by Abraham, and how does it connect to the theme of divine promise in Genesis?
questions.correctAnswer: He laughs
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:6 shows Sarah saying, 'God hath made me to laugh,' highlighting the joy and miraculous nature of Isaac's birth, connecting to the theme of God's fulfilled promise and laughter as a response to divine intervention.

questions.question: At what age was Isaac circumcised, and what does this ritual signify in the covenantal relationship between God and Abraham's descendants?
questions.correctAnswer: Eight days old
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:4 states that Abraham circumcised Isaac at eight days old, signifying the covenant God established with Abraham's descendants, a key marker of identity and faithfulness in ancient Israel.

questions.question: Why did Sarah demand the expulsion of Hagar and her son Ishmael, and how does this reflect ancient Near Eastern inheritance customs?
options: To prevent Ishmael from being heir with Isaac
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent Ishmael from being heir with Isaac
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:10 clearly shows Sarah's concern that Ishmael, the son of the bondwoman, should not share inheritance with Isaac, reflecting the cultural importance of legitimate lineage and inheritance rights in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: In the narrative of Hagar and Ishmael, what divine assurance is given about Ishmael's future, and how does this foreshadow later biblical nations?
options: God will make him a great nation
He will be king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God will make him a great nation
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:13 states God's promise to make Ishmael a nation, foreshadowing the emergence of peoples descended from Ishmael, linking to the broader biblical theme of God's care beyond Israel.

questions.question: How does Abraham’s covenant with Abimelech at Beersheba reflect ancient treaty practices?
options: Exchange of sheep and oxen and oath-swearing
questions.correctAnswer: Exchange of sheep and oxen and oath-swearing
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:27-31 describes Abraham giving sheep and oxen and both parties swearing an oath, typical of ancient Near Eastern treaties to formalize agreements and ensure mutual respect and rights.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the narrative where Sarah laughs upon hearing she will bear a son, and how does this relate to broader biblical themes?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: Sarah’s laughter in Genesis 21:6 is ironic because she laughs at the idea of bearing a child in old age, yet God fulfills this promise, illustrating the biblical theme of God overturning human expectations.

questions.question: What does the well discovered by Hagar signify in the context of survival and divine provision in the wilderness?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s provision for Ishmael’s survival
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:19 describes God opening Hagar’s eyes to a well, symbolizing divine care and provision even in desolate circumstances, a motif recurring throughout Scripture where God sustains His people.

questions.question: How does the name 'Beersheba' reflect the covenant made between Abraham and Abimelech, and what does it mean?
questions.correctAnswer: Well of the oath
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:31 explains that Beersheba means 'Well of the oath,' commemorating the covenant and oath sworn by Abraham and Abimelech, emphasizing the importance of sworn agreements in their culture.

questions.question: True or False: Abraham planted a grove in Beersheba and called on the name of the LORD, the everlasting God, highlighting monotheistic worship.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:33 states that Abraham planted a grove and called on the name of the LORD, the everlasting God, underscoring early monotheistic worship and the enduring nature of God’s covenant.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Abraham was ______ years old when Isaac was born, emphasizing the miraculous nature of the birth in his old age.
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:5 clearly states Abraham was one hundred years old at Isaac’s birth, highlighting the fulfillment of God’s promise despite natural impossibilities.

questions.question: What role does the angel of God play in the story of Hagar and Ishmael, and how does this reflect theological themes of divine intervention?
options: Calls to Hagar and reassures her
Leads Abraham to the promised land
questions.correctAnswer: Calls to Hagar and reassures her
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:17-18 shows the angel of God calling to Hagar from heaven, comforting and instructing her, which reflects God’s active involvement and care for marginalized individuals.

questions.question: How does the narrative of Isaac’s weaning and the feast given by Abraham function within the literary structure of Genesis 21?
options: Marks a transition from infancy to childhood
questions.correctAnswer: Marks a transition from infancy to childhood
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:8 notes the feast at Isaac’s weaning, a cultural milestone marking his growth, which structurally sets the stage for ensuing family conflicts and covenant developments.

questions.question: What is the significance of Ishmael becoming 'an archer' in the wilderness, and how does this detail connect to his future as a progenitor of nations?
options: Indicates his skill and survival in desert life
Means he was a warrior in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Indicates his skill and survival in desert life
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:20 describes Ishmael as an archer, symbolizing his adaptation and flourishing in wilderness conditions, which aligns with the biblical portrayal of his descendants as a distinct people.

questions.question: How does God's command to Abraham to 'hearken unto Sarah’s voice' concerning Hagar and Ishmael reflect the development of the Abrahamic covenant?
options: It prioritizes Isaac as the covenant heir
It commands expulsion of all servants
questions.correctAnswer: It prioritizes Isaac as the covenant heir
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:12 emphasizes the primacy of Isaac in God's covenant promises, showing a theological development where Isaac is established as the chosen seed through whom the covenant will continue.

questions.question: Which later biblical theme is foreshadowed by the covenant between Abraham and Abimelech in Genesis 21?
questions.correctAnswer: Peaceful coexistence with neighboring nations
questions.explanation: The covenant in Genesis 21:22-34 models peaceful relations and mutual respect between God's people and their neighbors, a theme that recurs in later biblical history.

questions.question: True or False: Abraham’s sojourning in the Philistines' land after the covenant signifies ongoing tension between God's people and their neighbors.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:34 mentions Abraham sojourning in Philistine land, indicating a period of peaceful residence but also underlying tension and the reality of living among potentially hostile peoples.

theological.title: Genesis Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Genesis Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What significant theological truth is demonstrated by God fulfilling His promise to Sarah regarding Isaac's birth?
options: God is faithful and sovereign over time
God changes His mind based on human prayer
God's promises are conditional on human works
questions.correctAnswer: God is faithful and sovereign over time
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:1-2 shows God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promise to Sarah despite her old age, affirming His sovereignty and unchanging nature, consistent with Numbers 23:19, 2 Timothy 2:13, Hebrews 10:23, and Psalm 33:11.

questions.question: What is the significance of Abraham circumcising Isaac on the eighth day?
options: It signifies covenant obedience as commanded by God
It was a cultural tradition unrelated to faith
It marked Isaac as a priest of the Lord
It was done to protect Isaac from illness
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies covenant obedience as commanded by God
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:4 emphasizes obedience to God's covenant command, establishing circumcision as the sign of the covenant, echoed in Leviticus 12:3, Romans 4:11, Colossians 2:11, and Genesis 17:10-11.

questions.question: How does Sarah's declaration that 'God hath made me to laugh' reflect a theological theme?
options: It highlights joy in God's miraculous intervention
It shows disbelief in God's promises
It reveals human skepticism toward God
It is a sarcastic comment on God's timing
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights joy in God's miraculous intervention
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:6 illustrates the joy and wonder at God's miraculous act, reflecting themes of divine blessing and fulfillment as in Psalm 126:2, Luke 1:58, Isaiah 65:14, and James 1:17.

questions.question: Why did Sarah demand that Hagar and Ishmael be sent away?
options: To protect Isaac's inheritance as God's appointed heir
Because she hated Hagar without cause
To punish Abraham for his past decisions
Because Ishmael had committed a crime
questions.correctAnswer: To protect Isaac's inheritance as God's appointed heir
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:10 reveals Sarah's concern for the covenant promise through Isaac, consistent with God's declaration in verse 12, supported by Romans 9:7-8, Galatians 4:28-31, and Hebrews 11:18.

questions.question: How does God's instruction to Abraham about Ishmael reflect His providence?
options: God promises to make Ishmael a great nation despite sending him away
God shows partiality only to Isaac
God allows human decisions to override His plan
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to make Ishmael a great nation despite sending him away
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:13 shows God's providential care beyond the covenant line, affirming His justice and mercy, in line with Genesis 16:10-12, Isaiah 60:7, Romans 11:29, and Psalm 103:17-18.

questions.question: What does Abraham’s early morning provision for Hagar and Ishmael demonstrate about his character?
options: Obedience mingled with compassion and responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience mingled with compassion and responsibility
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:14 highlights Abraham’s faithfulness to God's direction while caring for Hagar and Ishmael, reflecting biblical themes of loving obedience as seen in Exodus 20:12, Ephesians 6:2-3, Proverbs 3:5-6, and Matthew 22:37-40.

questions.question: How does God’s response to Hagar’s distress exemplify His attribute of omniscience and mercy?
options: God hears and intervenes to save Ishmael
God remains silent in human suffering
God punishes Hagar for her despair
God ignores the plight of the outcast
questions.correctAnswer: God hears and intervenes to save Ishmael
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:17-19 depicts God's intimate knowledge and merciful action, consistent with Psalm 34:18, Isaiah 41:10, Matthew 10:29-31, and Hebrews 4:15-16.

questions.question: What theological significance is found in Ishmael becoming an archer dwelling in the wilderness?
options: It symbolizes survival and God's blessing outside the covenant line
It means Ishmael was excluded from God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes survival and God's blessing outside the covenant line
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:20-21 portrays God's blessing on Ishmael’s descendants, affirming God's providence beyond Abraham’s covenant family, paralleling themes in Isaiah 54:1-3, Psalm 107:35, Jeremiah 31:35-37, and Romans 9:25.

questions.question: What does the covenant between Abraham and Abimelech teach about God's sovereignty over human relations?
options: God works through human agreements to fulfill His purposes
Human covenants are irrelevant to God's plan
questions.correctAnswer: God works through human agreements to fulfill His purposes
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:22-32 shows God’s providential guidance over peaceful resolutions, consistent with Proverbs 16:7, Psalm 85:10, Romans 13:1-7, and 2 Corinthians 5:18-20.

questions.question: Why did Abraham set seven ewe lambs apart during the covenant with Abimelech?
options: To serve as a witness to the well he had dug
To offer a sacrifice to God
questions.correctAnswer: To serve as a witness to the well he had dug
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:28-30 highlights the use of lambs as a tangible witness to the covenant agreement, reflecting biblical practices of covenant ratification found in Genesis 15:9-17, Exodus 24:4-8, Jeremiah 34:18-20, and Hebrews 9:18-22.

questions.question: What is the significance of the place name Beersheba in this chapter?
options: It symbolizes a solemn covenant and divine oath
It was a common watering place with no spiritual meaning
It was the capital city of the Philistines
It was a site of idol worship
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes a solemn covenant and divine oath
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:31-32 associates Beersheba with covenant-making and divine testimony, consistent with themes in Joshua 24:2-27, 1 Samuel 7:12, Psalm 89:34, and Jeremiah 34:18-20.

questions.question: What does Abraham’s planting of a grove and calling on the name of the LORD at Beersheba reveal about his faith?
options: It shows his worship and recognition of God as everlasting
It was a cultural custom with no religious significance
questions.correctAnswer: It shows his worship and recognition of God as everlasting
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:33 illustrates Abraham’s devotion and acknowledgment of God’s eternal nature, aligned with Deuteronomy 6:13, Psalm 90:2, Isaiah 40:28, and Revelation 1:8.

questions.question: How does Genesis 21 contribute to the doctrine of election and promise in salvation history?
options: It affirms God's sovereign choice of Isaac's line for the covenant
It teaches that all descendants have equal covenant status
It denies God’s involvement in human lineage
It shows that human effort determines election
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God's sovereign choice of Isaac's line for the covenant
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:12 emphasizes election, consistent with Romans 9:10-13, Ephesians 1:4-6, John 15:16, and 2 Timothy 1:9, showing God's sovereign plan in salvation history.

questions.question: What does the narrative of Hagar and Ishmael teach about God's care for those outside the covenant community?
options: God is merciful and provides for all His children
God ignores those outside the covenant
God’s promises are exclusive and exclusive only
questions.correctAnswer: God is merciful and provides for all His children
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:17-21 shows God's mercy to Ishmael, paralleling Psalm 145:9, Matthew 5:45, Jonah 4:2, and Luke 15:7, illustrating God's universal compassion.

questions.question: How does Abraham’s interaction with Abimelech demonstrate the principle of peace and justice in God’s economy?
options: It models covenantal integrity and conflict resolution
It shows that conflict is inevitable and unresolved
It encourages exploitation of weaker parties
It teaches that God approves of violence
questions.correctAnswer: It models covenantal integrity and conflict resolution
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:23-27 exemplifies peaceful negotiation under God’s guidance, consistent with Matthew 5:9, Romans 12:18, Proverbs 3:17, and Hebrews 12:14.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is hinted at through God’s promise to make Ishmael a great nation?
options: God’s blessing extends beyond immediate covenant people to future nations
Only Isaac’s descendants will have a future
The other nations are cursed eternally
God’s promises are limited to one ethnic group
questions.correctAnswer: God’s blessing extends beyond immediate covenant people to future nations
questions.explanation: Genesis 21:13 points to God’s universal plan, echoed in Genesis 12:3, Psalm 67:1-7, Isaiah 49:6, and Revelation 7:9-10, anticipating the inclusion of all nations in God’s redemptive plan.
